subject: Gardening
title: Kenroku-en: Six Attributes of Perfection
description: A quick, practical guide to Kenroku-en: Six Attributes of Perfection.

hook.text: Japan's most celebrated garden is named for possessing six qualities that no garden should have simultaneously.

buildup.text: Kenroku-en in Kanazawa took 200 years to build, spanning the reigns of multiple feudal lords.

discovery.text: Its name means 'garden of six sublimities': spaciousness, seclusion, artifice, antiquity, water, and panoramas.

twist.text: Traditional garden theory says these qualities conflictâ€”spaciousness negates seclusion. Kenroku-en achieves all six.

climax.text: The garden changes completely with each season. Winter snow on pine trees is considered its most beautiful form.

punchline.text: Perfection took 200 years and six impossible qualities.

quiz.question: Why is Kenroku-en's name significant?
options: It means 'garden of six sublimities'â€”qualities traditionally considered impossible to combine
It was built by six successive feudal lords
It contains exactly six distinct garden areas
